job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Muncie, IN
pros: Helping patients to heal was rewarding. Christmas parties  were enjoyable. Considered some coworkers friends. Went on to find a job elsewhere for IU Health and was happy with that.
cons: Was hired for an 8-5 job that turned out to be require being at work starting as early as 5:15AM and leaving as late as 8PM. Was told it was a “family,” but most toxic workplace I have experienced. Staff  meetings were a 1-3 hour event used to lecture and attack staff in front of the others. Extreme micromanaging where staff were told not to make decisions themselves, but when staff asked questions these questions were met with eye rolling, sighs and “I have to do everything around here.” When staff stood up for themselves concerns were dismissed and staff were accused of creating tension. Also would refer to these employees as defiant or “not team players.” Staff were asked “did you have a good day off while I was here working” framed as a joke if they took PTO. Staff were made to feel guilty should they refuse to come in on scheduled days off to work and rarely took PTO.  Cultivated an environment of fear with high turnover and a core group of staff who remained because they were desensitised or scared of finding a worse job elsewhere. Attempts to report toxic workplace were dismissed and no response was ever obtained from multiple anonymous workplace surveys. Staff were scared to report actions further up to chain due to fear of backlash for themselves or their coworkers to experience a more hostile environment. Writer was denied an exit interview.

review_title: Other hospitals in the IU Health System are Great, this review focuses on Bloomington
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Bloomington, IN
pros: System CEO is genuinely a nice man, and very astute about recognizing the actual root of issues, rather than accepting excuses. He also understood the mental health toll the pandemic was taking on those it impacted most and in an open letter he strongly encouraged leaders to support their staff when they were showing signs of burnout and mental distress. I floated to many hospitals within the IU system and enjoyed my time at all of them, feeling respected and appreciated for my work and treated with kindness, but especially Paoli, Bedford, West, and Arnett.
cons: Bloomington has a leadership toxicity problem. The CEO was nice, and the manager of the ICU was reasonable and fair, and always kind, but many of the other managers were, at minimum, dismissive of your concerns, and more often just openly rude. Hardly any ever showed any compassion for nurses working chronically short staffed, 60 hours a week, and one actually threatened to write me up for staying after my shift to chart for an hour on a night I had 6 very I’ll PCU patients. They did not care that a surge in Covid patients was going on at Bloomington, you were still expected to get things done as if it was normal business. I was never so happy as I was when my contract was up at bloomington, not because of the work, but because of how managers failed to treat employees with compassion. They also openly gossiped about employees which is just gross.

review_title: Good Locally, Bad at the Top
job_title: RN Ambulatory Surgery in Carmel, IN
pros: Job is not hard, great supportive management team, team environment, encourage growth and positivity.
cons: PTO is a huge issue and IU at the upper management levels are about money. They have lost tons of providers due to greed (half of anesthesia left and they have had to cancel surgeries). Holiday pay comes out of your PTO, so if you work 12s you get much less vacation due to that. Constant worry to have enough time. Benefits are high deductible and you have to watch every bill. CEO still gets his 2 mil annual bonus though

pros: Great team members, the culture at the bottom is great. After several years, they are finally providing maternity leave in 2023. Looking at pay and increasing certain jobs compensation that have been underpaid for years (no backpay or recognition for those of us who have stayed even though we have been underpaid 10k).
cons: With IUH being so large and matrixed, it has different pros and cons depending on the region and area you work. For instance, clinical and business is completely different worlds when you are talking about young professional support, job growth opportunities and leadership style and support.

pros: Inclusive culture, generally employee focused, and VERY AFFORDABLE healthcare benefits.
cons: Lots of questions regarding the motivations and goal setting methodology by leadership. Lots of one size fits all thinking, and if your non clinical role/management prepare to bang your head on the wall wondering who is making top down decisions affecting your departments. Additionally, HR seems to drive this organization. Admirable, if your in business for your employees, but not if your in business for the patient or outcomes. For example, your employees can have over 25+ attendance occurrences before you can even have a think about termination. I've seen employees threaten HR to take the earbud out of their ear and say, "see what happens". They kept their job and the manager was the one who received "difficult conversations training".... One person had over 45+ attendance occurrences and HR still forced management to work with employee to make their schedule more accomodating...for them. There is no way you can run a department and keep toxic people by a "hold hands, sing, and uplift" approach.

job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist (RRT) in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Good teamwork, multiple specialties, 401k match, choice of PPO vs HDHP, good charting system (Cerner)
cons: IU Health offered horrible pay compared to the market before the Covid crisis. Now, other area hospitals are increasing their frontline worker's pay substantially, and giving huge bonuses. IU Health currently has a premium pay contract for RNs and RTs that pays excellent, but we are not allowed to take any PTO, even prior approved PTO while we're in the contract. So now we have a ton of frontline clinical staff who are burnt out and depressed, and won't have had any time off for six months once this contract is over. But they supposedly care about our mental health. The assignments we go out with are huge and unsafe. Management does nothing to recruit new people, only hire travelers. We have lost so many therapists over the last couple of years, even ones with many years of experience and employment. There is no care for retention. For being a "state of the art facility", we have way too much equipment that doesn't work. 95% of the time, we do not get to have a lunch. We don't have coverage, so we're constantly being called away from our lunch.

pros:
Flexible work hours
Remote work
Good benefits, remotely affordable plans
My current team is awesome
cons: They have basically forced our hands. Employees are now required to take the experimental covid vaccine or lose our jobs by Sept. While I don't agree with forcing employees to get vaccines they don't want or believe, it is an understandable requirement for the in-person positions. But to force this on remote employees who have no contact with anyone is ridiculous! Furthermore, they continue to show how little they value employees. Once again, a hard-earned bonus was placed into our 401K's without any input from us! Due to the low wages we are paid, I know several employees who could've benefited much more from receiving that bonus in a paycheck. Oh yeah, speaking of bonuses, when we did get our first one in FIVE years, it was highly taxed! I didn't even know we had gotten it! IU Health portrays itself to be this leader in healthcare, so patient focused with these awesome employees...Don't believe the hype! ALL they care about is the bottom line. MONEY! They don't care what we have to do as long as we ensure they continue to bring in millions a year so they can keep paying their executives top dollar while we get nothing but .9 cent yearly raises! This is truly the worst place I have ever worked and I cannot wait to find another place of employment!

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
-Amazing response to the pandemic. Leader in sending employees home and keeping us updated on all fronts. Organization seems to be trending to the idea of 'work where you're most comfortable' as a result.
-Culture is great things are being done to make it continuous. Remember that culture in healthcare is tricky with the vast majority of employees being patient-facing.
cons:
-Year over year compensation is very rough. It's no secret the pandemic took its toll on businesses, but to not even offer performance based reviews for a raise and not meet yearly inflation blows my mind. My first year without the pandemic had raises just below inflation. Company gives everyone $500 bonus, regardless of rank, performance, nurse/doctor/accountant/etc, While nice, it doesn't move the needle when the compensation and benefits is already subpar.
-No paid holidays, no sick days...must always use PTO. You get 28 PTO days as an incentive during interviewing, but if you're sick (non-COVID) or it's Christmas Day, then you have to use 8 hours. This is ridiculous for administrative staff and to be treated under the same umbrella as medical staff. No one wants to work here for a year+ just to be able to take a week vacation and holidays while not worrying about PTO.
-There is no succession plan. I still have yet to hear a single mention of what it takes to advance in this Company (2 years in). I have raised my hand and asked too.
-Equipment is extremely out of date. The laptop currently in use by staff is extremely old, slow, and bulky.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Indianapolis, IN
pros: I loved my night shift team. We are already at a disadvantage with less resources working nights, however, the support there was great! I love the support from most of my charge nurses as well. When I worked on days, that was a completely different story. It's a teaching hospital, so you will learn A LOT! I'm very grateful of my short opportunity learning there. Don't get me wrong, the floor I worked on is very difficult (probably one of most difficult floor according to most resource and float nurses), and I had days where I was ready to quit on the spot. Most all the night shift nurses and tech can agree with me. We had it rough, but we came through for each other always extending a helping hand.
cons: I worked there for almost 2 years and the management went down hill quick. It was my very first nursing job (started on days then switched to nights) and I have never seen so many nurses leaving or transferring to different units or sister hospitals. Just on my particular unit, there were several clicks who only help support each other. If they have vibes of not liking you/ your personality, they will show it by not helping you as much when you ask for it and talking behind your back. This pushed me switch to night shift. . Not every part of the hospital is like that. I quickly learned that you are replaceable, ALWAYS replaceable. Always put your personal health and well-being FIRST. I quickly learned my well-being will always come before any job, nursing or not. With the overwhelming amount of stress from the high acuity patients, it will take a toll. However, learning from those patients and their illness are well worth it and greatly increases your nursing knowledge.

review_title: A Great Institution in a great Industry but hindered by Leadership
pros:
Nice Health Benefits
Opportunity to work in a multi-campus environment. This is for those that like to move around
Offers meaningful work. You can actually say you are helping save lives, and mean it
The company uses the latest technologies and has very sophisticated ones too
Treats employees with respect and dignity
Offers top quality medical care to its patients
cons:
Not competitive in it's salaries
Poor decision making on the part of Senior Management. Three specific examples below:
Changed name from "Indiana University Medical Group" to "Indiana Clinic" and then again to "Indiana University Health Physicians" all within a 24 month period.
Communicated to employees that the state of the Hospital was strong in January only to layoff over 1000 workers in October the same year.
Lacked foresight to see the changes in reimbursement being heralded in Congress and the media. Embarked on a buying and building spree one year, only to consider shutting down one of its flagship campuses - "Indiana University" Hospital  in 2 years.

pros: Good pay, reasonable benefits, nice atmosphere, rarely called off, most of staff nurses are supportive and helpful when over whelmed with severity of pt. care load / emergency situations.
cons: Upper management is not well versed on actual needs and concerns of floor staff, do not supervise unit managers treatment of employees, unit managers take patients sides and does not listen to employees explanations regarding patient complaints, no upper management or unit managers ever make rounds on night shift to stay in touch and address issues the staff may have.  Employees have been verbally threatened, received physical harassment and discrimination by others and nothing is done. Assignments of patients are not based on acuity, leaving one with much heavier assignment while others have a light assignment.

job_title: Registered Nurse, Critical Care in Indianapolis, IN
pros: I absolutely love my coworkers.  The nurses I work with as a bedside nurse in Critical care exemplify teamwork, and my direct management does the best that they can to support us.
cons: Upper management has completely disrespected the staff and lower management.  The benefit package is a complete disgrace.  My son has cerebral palsy, and he aged out of the First Steps program on his 3rd birthday.  When he was 2 and a half, I began to try to get him scheduled at the Riley Outpatient Rehab -- the only in-network provider that is offered -- and was told there was a 6 month waiting list.  That was fine -- we had six months before his First Steps therapies ended.  When he turned three, I called the scheduling line at Riley and was told that tree is NOW a NINE month wait for therapy.  Nine months in the life of a three year old with disabilities is an eternity!  That was the day I began looking for other employment opportunities.

pros: My clinical managers were amazing and supportive, my colleagues were fun to work with and very helpful, busy days help the time fly by, high acuity patients increased my knowledge base.  Each unit has a shared governance council, which made me feel like my voice was being heard.  Great reimbursement for certifications and additional education.  Self-scheduling on my unit allowed for fantastic work-life balance. My unit's culture was one of teamwork, but that is most definitely unit-specific.
cons: Our day shift differential (from 15:00-19:00) was taken away, management above the level of my clinical manager seemed to turn a blind eye to the fact that increasing RN:patient ratios were causing nurses to jeopardize their licenses by practicing unsafely (not to mention the undue harm it caused the patients).  Lesser quality products were introduced to save money.  During the last half of all my hard work in advancing from Associate Partner to Partner, the clinical ladder program was halted until further notice.
