pros: I think very intelligent nurses and other staff work here, there are many competent people willing to sacrifice themselves to their jobs.
cons: Main CEO (Evans) doesn't understand the culture of bedside care and focuses on too much of a business perspective. Dishonest, biased reasoning for wage cuts and layoffs like the ACA (which has actually helped many of my patients pay their medical bills). Unfair absence policy only gives 4 sick times (or less depending on location) in a year with disciplinary points after 3-4 unplanned absences. Meaning if you are sick once in April and call in, you will have that counted against you until April of the following year. Nurses work sick. Also don't have the staff needed to provide safe care. Nurse to patient ratio usually above grid and borders unsafe. Management demonstrates lack of respect for professionals. Salary is well below national average and nurses in some IU health locations start around $22.33 per hour. Entire IU health system is like a monopoly and doesn't factor in the different needs of different locations across Indiana.

job_title: Registered Nurse MSN in Camby, IN
pros: Many locations to choose from and competitive pay
cons: Some issues with staffing at times

job_title: Certified Surgical Technologist in Indianapolis, IN
pros: I love the staff and doctors
cons: I do not like the management

pros: A lot of experiences to have.
cons: Management did not always put effective people in place.

pros: Location, Benefits, Company Name and Learning
cons: Poor management and very low pay. Attitudes with coworkers

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Good PTO for length of service
cons: New RNs get larger % raises than those with tenure.

pros: Nice experience, good team work
cons: I don't have any negative to tell

pros: great experience and good teamwork
cons: management left things to be desired

pros: Bonuses, understanding management, good learning experience.
cons: Too many patients for one assignment.

job_title: "Responsable de marketing, prensa y comunicación" in La Porte, IN
pros:
Awesome director. One of the best anyone could possibly ask for. Also one of the few left standing after all the firings of management staff. 

Very good colleagues. 

It was once a great place to work when it was just La Porte Regional Healthcare and Thor Thordesson was not CEO.
cons:
Administrative team - The CEO's "uncommon leader" vision has done nothing but decrease employee morale by terminating employees who've been very dedicated to the organization for many years. It has created an environment of fear as many people at all levels are worried about job security. 

Many departments are short staffed the administrative team is telling all employees to cut operational expenses yet somehow they found the money to have 11 vice presidents in an organization with less than 2000 employees. 

There is very high turnover rate at the hospital. 

Nepotism - People get promoted by who they are related to and their political ties and not their job performance.

review_title: Greed Based since IU took over.
pros: High quality health care in most areas.
cons: Since IU took over, the company is totally greed based.  They have cut benifits and pay to their employees.  If you do some research, you'll find hospital employees actually pay more than most companies for health insurance.  IU passes the real costs along to the employees and banks their contributions. If they don't use that, they get their contribution back.  The company blames Health Care Reform on their shortfalls and reductions while posting record profits.  They consistently build new 200 million dollar buildings but don't have money for staff.  The new IU management is cut throat, not using logic to keep the best people.  It's all about numbers and hoarding money for a few at the top.  The CEO and COO make a combined 8 million a year, more than any other health company in the Midwest.  Also be careful donating to Riley.  The are happy to take your money, but where's it going to.  They take in many millions a year, but still bill full price.  IU Health also charges triple for test.  For example, a HIDA Scan at IU Saxony is $2000 plus the radiologists fee.  At North Side Radiology, the same test is $760 (including the radiologists fee).  Remember, they are greed based, they don't care about you.

pros: Large stable company, many internal opportunities
cons:
Each year since the merger w/IU Health, it has become increasingly apparent this is a business just like any other- focused on the bottom line, not employees or patients.  

We are continually asked to do more (increasing patient volume and acuity, productivity, more tasks added) and with less and less (fewer employees, no increase in pay, less equipment, less time with each patient, etc.), with nothing less than perfection expected.  The physicians are also expected to maintain an extremely high level of productivity with patient volume and procedures.  Burnout is real.

Very frustrating as an employee, when I can't give my best care because I don't have enough time or resources.  Very scary as a patient- when everyone is past their max capacity, things get missed, confused, and forgotten.  This is why I am not proud to work here.

pros: my coworkers, decent health insurance
cons:
-HR is a joke- I had nothing but problems with them any time I had to work with them, including attempting to get my PTO paid out after I left (still haven't received it because they won't do the paperwork on their end) and trying to get my husband added to my insurance took almost 2 months because they kept losing the forms I sent them, wouldn't return phone calls and emails, and just in general have no idea what they're doing
-the organization as a whole does not care about their employees
-you can earn a lot of PTO but good luck trying to use it
-the hospital "hierarchy" is alive and well here with many, many rude doctors and nurses
-the culture is just overall unenjoyable with poor management
-took away the option to take holidays unpaid which in effect takes 6 of your PTO days that you were originally guaranteed. 
-while patient care staff are worked to the bone, admins get to enjoy flexible schedules and company paid for baseball games. 
-the patients don't matter to management, all they care about is money and are pushing towards worse and worse patient care and just cranking out numbers. 
-for being "a leader in healthcare" they treat pregnant women and new mothers quite poorly.

pros:
I like working on my unit with my coworkers
I don’t have to live in a ditch
cons:
No Rn or PCA staff EVER. Dangerous and no one seems to care whether we have enough workers to care for some really sick patients.
Only worries about the budget and not staff retention
Many managers are 
Poor insurance benefits
Many many rude staff members even I have witnessed nasty comments to patients who have done nothing wrong from different workers and nothing is done about it
Our CNO is a joke. Doesn’t care about anyone but herself
They changed the raise scale (this could be IU wide) and it’s terrible. Better to change jobs every few years

We also find bed bugs ALL THE TIME. not even only from patients they are in our chairs and beds. No one will do anything about this and you have to catch a bug to show to the supervisor in order to call bug control, but since bedbugs hide in the light this is impossible. Anything to save a buck

All the do is cut staffing and make us work shorter and shorter. I’ve never seen my unit manager come in a help but they also yell at us for overtime even if it compromises patient safety.

review_title: Too many changes, too fast, with very little communication
pros: Interactions with co-workers and other staff members can be very supportive if there is a good mix of individuals.  The innovative ideas that come from hospital staff is very uplifting.
cons: Middle and upper management do not do very well with communicating with each other or staff which in turn trickles down to staff.  There are too many cliques within the organization.  Information does not get disseminated to staff timely or at all.  The insurance benefits are pretty lousy given that one works within the hospital network.

pros: This is a great place to get and use experience caring for critically ill patients. Coworkers are excellent and caring. High standards for care and use of evidence based data to improve patient outcomes.
cons: Serious issues with patient-nurse ratios for extended period of time (2 years). Upper management does not listen to the bedside nurses regarding need for more staff to provide adequate care for all patients under their care. Management is very slow to respond to obvious problems. Forced reduction in salary and layoffs under guise of cutbacks required to economically weather healthcare cutbacks related to ACA. Attendance policy is unreasonable in a profession where many providers are mothers and single mothers and are exposed to illness on a regular basis.

review_title: Cardiac Cath Lab is a Miserable Place
pros: Helping patients is very motivating, too bad the culture of Cath Lab distracts from the true purpose that we work for.
cons: The management is very much not in touch with right and wrong and displays a large lack of integrity.  The culture is the worst I have seen in my many years being a nurse.    There is not a patient first culture and patients are routinely put at risk.  The management makes decisions that are not in the best interest of the Cath lab and the management does not care about the employees.  It is so bad that outside help has been brought in to help improve the culture, but all it has done is reinforce the bad culture.  Individuals are allowed to act horribly to each other and management turns a blind eye.  There is a culture of bullying and any attempt to make things better by bringing up concerns is responded to by retaliation.  Do NOT apply for a job in the Cath lab, you will regret the decision.

pros: Ability to work for a well-known company with ability to transfer within the organizatoin. Salary is decent compared to National Average but not accurate with responsibilities/expectations from upper level management.
cons: Corporate Supply Chain turnover is near 35% in the last 4 years. Team Lead, Director are  micro managers and are clueless on the amount of time it actually takes to complete projects.  Interview does not thouroughly explain the position and employees are struggling from the first day.  Training is minimal except for ERP System basics.  As turnover continues leadership is pushing projects to existing team members without budging timeline which ultimately makes them transfer as well.  They will tell you its a 45hour work week to maintain work/life balance but realistically its 60+ to stay afloat, 65 to 70+ hours to complete adequately complete tasks.

review_title: Registered Nurse IU Health Ball Memorial Hospital
pros: Co workers, but everyone leaves so fast
cons: Very dangerous place to work, the staffing is horrible you will take6-7 patients even on telemetry units MTU  with drips. They do not care about their patients or staff.  The workload is horrible and every year they cut nurses and replace them with nurses aides who can not do your work!  Every employee I know says they would never allow their family to come here for care and that really says something.  This is by far the most dangerous place to work I have ever seen, most nights I see nurses crying and no one in this entire place cares!  Every decision is based on money not care.  Do  yourself a favor and keep driving past this place!

pros: Multiple job opportunities to choose from.  Opportunities to grow professionally, skill-wise.
cons: Gradual elimination of growth opportunities and earning opportunities (scant pay increases, significant reduction in pay grades), reduction/elimination of incentives, increasing ratios without adequate, competent ancillary staff.  Corporate shows disinterest in maintaining seasoned staff and incentives to keep interest of less experienced staff, i.e, large turnover staffing issues, use of contractors.  Corporate will survey staff for opinions, but doesn't give them a vote. Harsh/punitive attendance policy that makes staff made unhealthy decisions.

review_title: No longer your small community hospital.
pros: Salary is in line with the industry.  Flexible hours.  Decent benefits.
cons: As small hospitals are "taken over", there seems to be a "play nice" period followed by a slow but sure termination of experienced staff with the explanation being "you are not the best person to take us in the direction we want to go" and new staff with less experience is brought in.  Staff and physicians are treated with a total lack of dignity and respect in spite of years of loyalty and dedication to patient care.  Money is now the bottom line.

job_title: Patient Care Assistant in Bloomington, IN
pros: The benefits are really good. It is a diverse staff. There is a very good work/life balance because of the way they schedule the staff.
cons: The staff is hateful and there is always some kind of gossip. It's like being in high school all over again. Upper management ignores the problems. They don't train very well and for a University Hospital I thought it would be more of a teaching environment. Nobody is willing to let people learn new things. As a tech for six months with 3 years of licensed experience in the field I am still not allowed to do things that are within my scope of practice. My starting pay doesn't reflect my experience and licensing. It is micromanaged and there is no accountability for the work you do.

pros: 401K company matches 3%. RT staff and administrative support teams give excellent patient care considering there are not enough support staff. Employees work well as a team. Team leads, and manager are positive and care about their team members, and providing excellent patient care.
cons: Lack of training, computer and copy machines are antiquated.Lack of communication  for employees working in satellite branches. There is a large patient load volume, and not enough support staff, causing staff to be overwhelmed  with work, increasing risk for errors. Lacking in consistency with policies among satellite offices, due to poor communication. Main office does not have a full understanding as to the autonomy of the satellite offices, therefore job performance reviews are inaccurately calculated, causing unfair performance reviews.

job_title: Human Resource Administration in Lafayette, IN
pros: Wonderful group of people to work with. Job variety keeps things interesting. The hours are consistent and there is a large degree of flexibility when taking breaks
cons: Not much training for someone who has no prior experience. The position I held was described as clerical, however once I was hired I received minimal training and expectations for the position were high.  I had no issue with the expectations being high except the expectations did not match what they were willing to invest in their employee.  Despite my offering to pay for my own training, since they felt sending me to training would be a "reward" they didn't feel I deserved, I was not permitted to get the training that was needed to perform the required tasks and subsequently terminated. Very frustrating situation since I liked my job and the people I worked with.

review_title: Clarian is an ok place to work
pros:
Clarian is the largest health care provider in the state of Indiana.  With its size, comes job stability and opportunities for growth.  Clarian provides a competitive benefits package and provides both an annual wage increase and a small bonus based on the performance of the company.

The corporate culture of Clarian seems to be positive in general.  There are constant reminders of what the vision of Clarian is and what the expectations of senior management are.   While there are always bad apples, overall my experience has been that people at Clarian are friendly and care about the work they are doing.
cons: Sometimes it seems like you can get lost in the system.  There are so many people it is hard to be rewarded for individual performance.  While you will get ahead by working hard, you will not get as far as fast as you would with other companies.

pros: Good salary, Benefits, Retirement, Most co-workers are friendly. Opportunity to meet a lot of really nice people of all levels of education and backgrounds, There is a lot of diversity. Opportunity to help others.
cons: Constant battles with homeless people in hospital lobby. Constantly dealing with unruly people who expect to be able to tell doctors and nurses what medications to give them. As in any other profession dealing with enforcing the rules you have people in law enforcement wanting to rough people up. You have some medical staff that have no tact as to cause a situation to spiral out of control.

pros: Easy to save money on insurance premiums by exercising, etc.
cons: PTO includes holiday, sick, and vacation pay although you are required to take the holiday off, so therefore holiday pay should be separate because it is not something you can control. They claim flexibility, but it is not at all flexible. Pay is lacking considering how many hours you have to work. There was no contact with HR in the interview process and no exit interview. I got a survey in the mail to fill out for my exit interview. Very impersonal. They are not open to new ideas, they would rather do things the way they have always been done and you should be a robot and do it regardless if you agree or not. No one is happy working there and it shows.

pros: Flex hours and unlimited OT (if you earn it)
cons: We are overworked, underpaid, we’re held accountable for everyone else’s jobs. We don’t get paid holidays (even though we cannot work those days) but we have to use the little pto that we earn each check for holidays. Some of us are forced to train new team members even though we aren’t team leads or senior analysts-meaning we aren’t technically qualified to do it. We aren’t given any bonuses or incentives to meet the nearly impossible production and quality metrics. I could go on and but I’m sure you get the picture.

pros:
-I love being in a position where I can help others
-Shift differential pay is a perk especially for hourly workers
-401k benefits are extended to those who aren't full-time
While working for IU almost 3 years, I've been able to fund my education without taking on a ton of debt. 
My supervisor, Bill Hand is amazing. He really cares for us and works really hard to work with my class schedule. If it wasn't for him I would have quit.
cons:
-Employees pay for parking at some hospitals
-Big communication gap between various departments
-Most non-clerical departments are very short staffed
-Change is often slow and executives are very out of touch 
-I haven't seen my actual manager more than 3 times in 3 years....

review_title: So many pros, very few cons
pros: Many great leaders, best healthcare provider in the community, opportunities for growth in both clinical and non-clinical positions, etc.  Also very happy to say that the system is making smart and calculated changes to coincide with the changes in the industry, in patient needs, and in the needs of it's employees.  Doing a better job keeping up with the times than most healthcare organizations.  Pay is what you can expect from a non-profit health system.  You'll get more in private settings but the work and the opportunities at those places will pale in comparison.
cons: There's a competitive PTO program for normal needs but there's nothing for maternity leave, let alone paternity leave.  Truly the one thing I can't be proud of here.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Great coworkers and management personnel, very caring and compassionate towards patients and associates, fun place to work, fast paced, always  busy, work is interesting and varied, opportunity to learn several systems
cons: High pressure, stressful, must always be mindful  of the performance scores which sometimes shifted focus from the patients.  Was not always able to help patients within the five minutes allowed for the call, if calls went over five minutes, it reflected badly  on performance score.

pros: One of the largest hospital systems in the nation; above average compensation; new employee roles are created often so there are options to move laterally into new positions
cons: Priorities change very often and projects are sometimes abandoned/never finished; management promotes working overtime (for salaried employees); very few options for flexible working hours if salaried; some members of non-senior management team need to improve their leadership skills

pros: Benefits/ Promote from within/ Ability to gain employment in other departments/
cons: We had Seven New Senior Managers within a two year period.  All of them had different paths, and no one seem to be able to work together.  The Supervisors made a point of playing the favoritism game with employees which caused problems in training based on the Merit system and not who is stroking my ego today.    Lots of gossipers' /  Have many immigrants on duty who you (as a Leader) have to have a translator to communicate with.  We have patients and customers from within who have needs and cannot communicate their needs because of language barriers between staff and them.

pros: Being involved with the latest in medical care and research; the co-workers in my department are great! The hospital (IU Health as it is now called) has been around for quite a while and as long as you don't have to get involved with senior management then it's a really great place to work.
cons: There is little consistency about what rules are followed and who gets promoted. Politics are more important than who is qualified to do a particular job. There needs to be a focus back on the employees and doing what is right.

review_title: A review of Methodist and IU West
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Avon, IN
pros: I worked for Methodist as a new RN for about four year in an adult critical care setting and loved it. The staff were all helpful in helping me get accustomed to my new role and become a successful critical care RN.  The only reason that I left and moved to IU West was because I had two more children and wanted to be a little closer to home. IU West has also been a wonderful place to work. I have been there for more than 12 years now and they have always been flexible with my schedule and encouraging of me continuing my education to be an FNP.
cons: I do not have a con. I have been PRN for the length of time of my employment and it has been great.

review_title: I think that they care more about the dollar then they do their patients or employees
pros: It was nice to work for a very large company but in time that was used against you. They could bring in new people and pay them less and let go the people that had been there for years because they had climbed the payscale.
cons: To much change within management  and favoritism basically ruled the company. Employee's that work at IU today or either there because they are related to upper management or close friends of upper management.

job_title: Sterile Procesinng Technician in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Friendly co-workers, great sense of teamwork. Opportunities for advancement in the department with classes paid for by IU Health or reimbursed. Very thorough in the orientation training for my department and made me feel very comfortable learning my position and asking questions. Absolutely love the management and department educators!
cons: HR gives the impression to be out of touch with employees' needs and concerns, HR is not very forthcoming and informative of the benefits offered by the company; I actually had to be educated about my benefits and options by my fellow co-workers that have been with the company for a few years.

review_title: A great community hospital experiencing growing pains
pros: The hospital has done a good job of hiring friendly, compassionate professionals who are pleasant to work with. The benefit package is decent, and tuition reimbursement is on par with other institutions in the state.
cons: The hospital is going through some growing pains as it merges with "Indiana Health" and attempts to cement it's place as a regional referral center. Changes in policies and philosophy are made rapidly, which would not be a problem if the education department did a better job of disseminating information to the employees. Example: In the year I have worked there, we have changed the DNR policy at least 3 times.

review_title: Longterm employee working my way up
pros: I have work here over 10 years and had a wide variety of duties, but mostly stayed in the hospital.  I have met and still have great friends here, and it feels like home.  I appreciate the diversity of roles available and the opportunity to learn on the job skills.  I am still amazed of the organized complexity of "treating patients".  Each employee does matter, even if they never see or speak to our patients.
cons: Some great ideas are stifled with politics and red tape....unless you know the right person.  Sometimes it takes a while for upper management to recognize hard work and dedication.

review_title: I enjoyed working at Indiana University Health!  It was very rewarding asI served as Media Relations Coordinator.
job_title: Media Relations Coordinator in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Great salary and benefits.  Working with great people and helping patients and others within the hospital system is very rewarding.
cons: Human Resources doesn't tend to be very friendly or helpful in times of need.  Especially when asking questions about your supervisor....Also, many times I noticed those of us in the Corporate Communications department weren't considered for management positions as people were brought from the outside.  Not good!  Hurts moral and gets people to start looking for other positions with more upward mobility!

pros: Very diverse group of employees. Linked to the IU school of medicine so there are new doctors and new innovative treatments not available at other facilities. It's also one of the largest, if not the largest, healthcare system in Indiana making access that much easier. My supervisor has also been extremely flexible and understand and has gone out of her way to make sure that I am getting mandatory education done on time as well as sending me reminders about certain departmental changes.
cons: Recent issues with mandatory vaccinations, terminations of employment, and uniform changes. Many positions have strict qualifications making it difficult to find an entry level position.

review_title: Best Area to Work at IUHealth
job_title: Utilization Management RN in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
Supportive management & team leaders
Flexible remote work
Education continually provided to enhance our knowledge of Payor expectations, rules, etc, to help us do best job possible.
cons: Hard to find a con - but maybe some people might feel disconnected when working remote, away from hospital or a traditional office.  Our  management team really works hard to create a sense of Team and belonging among employees.  Also, tools/apps are available to connect with others doing same work.  I never really feel “alone” while I work.

pros: Good staff, caring medical professionals, reasonable pay, 3 12 hour shifts, opportunity for advancement, benefits start soon after hire, professional environment, treated with respect and dignity. Family feel on the unit I work on.
cons: Staffing shortages at times, benefit costs go up every year, invasive health track programs for insurance discounts, forced floating without regard to resource staff training at times, raises significantly less than competition across town.

job_title: Primary Care Physician in Indianapolis, IN
pros: They have  many very intelligent, hard-working doctors and administrators. They are dedicated to providing very high quality health care.
cons: It is a very large organization. Individual employees have little say in what they do. It is somewhat bureaucratic, and if the employee makes one mistake which might be embarrassing, he or she is likely to be fired regardless of how hard he or she has worked and how excellent their work was otherwise. They have had a hard time hiring primary care physicians for their offices in Marion County. The primary care physicians who are left are overworked.

review_title: you will learn alot in a short time but be prepared to work your butt off daily
pros: Diverse complicated patient base, fast paced shifts. you will see things here you have never seen anywhere else.
cons: Frequently understaffed, did I mention frequently?! Staff turnover, management only partially listens. I almost never got an uninterrupted lunch or break. Night supervisors didn't care if you were short staffed or patient acuity was thru the roof, you were doing to get that next.patient

pros: Very good corporate culture. Clarian Health focused on the mission of providing very good health care to both paying and charity customers. This made all employees feel like they were contributing to to betterment of society. Compensation and benefits are average for the health care profession. There are many different opportunities within the organization.
cons: Communication is a major problem at Clarian Health. There is very little communication between business units and locations. It is quite common for different units and/or locations to have the same problem. The problem is not addressed on a system wide basis. Each unit/location is allowed address the problem on a local level. This allows for inconsisitent results.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Most people are great to work with and company makes sure employees follow the rules, mission, vision and values of the company.  Growth potential is there if you want it.
cons: The company is top heavy and getting more so every day.  The lower rungs of the company need support personnel making work/home a little better.  Young people are not always the ones, even with education, to take the lead.

review_title: Good start to career at Methodist
pros: acuity of patients and senior physicians allowed for exceptional learning experiences and fostered enhancement of clinical skills and knowledge
cons: Unit was always short staffed . This caused nurses to show lateral violence against one another, hindering teamwork. Management could care less about these issues . PTO was a joke- everything is one bank. Ok that’s normal. However they do not care if you are sick or anything- you will get an occurrence. For being a hospital, this is absolutely ridiculous. If I come in with a fever, I’m sent home. If I call off due to a fever, I get written up? They are setting employees up for failure with this .

review_title: They have lost focus and fundamentals of healthcare.
pros: You have many different opportunities and different educational opportunities are offered.
cons: The company grew too fast. They are only focused on money, and have completely lost focus of what is really important and why their employees choose to enter healthcare. They undermine the philosphy healthcare is based on. It is no longer about caring for people or having the best interest of their employees or the patients. As a nurse, your license is in jeparody every single shift you work.

job_title: Radiologic Technologist in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Very friendly organization. Competitive pay, I received a pay raise over my previous position.  My experience has been the management really does care about staff. No matter what your education or experience all employees are highly regarded as people not numbers on a payroll.
cons: For me location is a bit of an issue.  I live 38 minutes from the nearest facility.  I was also required to buy uniform clothes prior to my first pay check, 1 free pair would help ease this hardship.

pros: IU Health serves a great mission in serving patients and changing peoples lives. In any department, it is clear that the patient comes first. IU Health offers great benefits for salaried employees. I enjoy the amount of time off I'm given, as well as the opportunity to take part in Lean training. Work life balance is also a plus.
cons: There aren't too many down sides. It is what you make it. In my department, my manager can be a little passive aggressive. But, that is not a reflection of the culture at IU Health.

pros: I was a non-clinical employee that started at IU Health North and ended up at the corporate offices. It was one of the most rewarding professional experiences of my career. Senior leadership really cared for employees and created a supportive, collaborative environment where people felt empowered to try new approaches and develop new skills. You could really own your work!
cons: I left the company after almost six years because, for as large as it was, there were not ample opportunities for me to continue progressing in my career -- even after earning an advanced degree. Internal promotions don't result in the same bump in pay as someone coming from the outside.

review_title: I love what I do but I don't love the organization I work for.
pros: I work in a laboratory. Because of the diversified client base, I get to see many unusual cases that wouldn't be seen in a smaller lab setting.
cons: Management doesn't listen to our concerns. Every year we complete an "employee satisfaction survey" but nothing is ever done with the results. Fortunately I don't have my health insurance thru my employer because I've heard nothing but complaints about it from my coworkers who do have it. Very little room for advancement unless you are tight with the management.

pros: Co-workers were some of the best people I've ever known
cons: HR is refusing to pay the PTO I earned working 60-70 hour weeks for a year even though I wasn't allowed to take it when I worked there. My boss didn't want to have to coordinate coverage for my job so I got denied PTO and then cannot get paid for it. Also the insurance is awful. It can only be used with certain locations/providers and the HSAs are poorly explained. The PPO is too expensive for the wages earned. They will work you to the bone and give you no flex time, no understanding, and no help. It all depends on the relationships you build with your coworkers.

pros: IU Health has a culture like no other employer I've worked for.  The compassion team members have for one another and our patients is outstanding. It creates a collaborative environment that truly makes it a joy to come to work every day.
cons: As with any big company, keeping technology up to date and investing in equipment/infrastructure is important. There are lots of great changes happening to address this, but these are big efforts and things constantly evolve.

pros: I love providing care for patients, teaching them about what we are doing to help them or their family member get better, helping them through a crisis situation, all the tasks that come with saving lives, surgery, procedures, etc.
cons: IU Health has become a huge conglomerate corporation with hundreds of "specialty" services at various locations- staff (RN and interns/residents) do not get the varied experience now that they would get before all the mergers. In addition, the great expansion of the company with the addition of West, North, Saxony, etc has provided ample opportunity for advancement for young managers.

job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Work in the RCP Department, and all of the RCPs have a wonderful attitude and great teamwork.  Always willing to help out when things get stressfull.
cons: Management not the best.  Manager does not listen to what employees are telling him.  He puts patient safety at risk by short staffing and bigger work loads.  His higher up does not care about the employees; in her words, "RTs are a dime a dozen, everyone is replaceable"  Because of management, department morale is at an all time low.

review_title: Policies made by upper management to retain employees actually drive them to leave
pros: Paid time off accruals are fairly generous.  Most of the staff there provide excellent patient care.  Employee perk program is good.
cons: Employee advancement program for nurses eliminated.  Change in policy requires nurses to stay on same unit for at least 1 year before transferring unless a waiver from upper management is granted.  So if an RN doesn't feel a unit is a good fit, even after giving it a fair shot (e.g. 6 months), the RN must either stay where he or she is unhappy or leave the organization.

pros: IU Health has excellent management and they truly seem to care about their employees. The benefits that they offer their employees are very nice and PTO can be accrued as soon as you start working there (there is no wait period)
cons: The opportunities for advancement within are not easy to come by. It seems like it is very difficult to get anyone to even look at your resume if you submit it via their IUH careers page online.

review_title: Co-workers are great, company not so  much
pros:
Decent Medical/Dental Plan but not as good as you would think working for a hospital
Co-Workers are great. You can develop lifelong friendships.
cons:
If you work downtown they make you pay for your own parking, which is shared with the university so finding a spot is hard then you have to walk several blocks to get to work. 
Despite getting "Top Performer" reviews, was told they couldn't give raises (for 4+ years in a row)

review_title: Poor Management, Poor treatment of nurses
pros: Many different nursing opportunities and room for advancement
cons: IU Health is a machine.  They do not treat nursing professionals like other professions.  They protect the other roles, and the nurses are like worker bees with little autonomy and expected to adapt to demands that are unreasonable.

review_title: I've been here long enough to see all the changes in the 20+ years and I like what I see.
pros: Our unit works well together and I have the best manager ever! The care that we give our patients is recognized by even the administration.
cons: You get to see the patients that get better and the ones who don't. Sometimes we become an extended family to our patients and the hurt is there when we lose someone.

review_title: Great learning experience - Poor management system
job_title: Patient Registration Specialist in Indianapolis, IN
pros: IU provides great training that gives employees a leg up on industry standards, protocols, and proper procedures.  It could be a stepping stone for learning opportunities for folks considering the medical industry.
cons:
Let me make it clear that I am not a disgruntled employee - I am a mature adult sharing my professional opinion of my work experience with IU Health.  In all fairness to IU - It is my understanding that department in which I worked has relieved several people of their duties including management, based on conversations I have had with current employees that still work there, but there are still problems. Now for my review
POOR COMPENSATION: Below average pay for the level of responsibility that is required of patient registration specialist; CAREER OPPORTUNITIES: Opportunities are dependent upon who you know and if your own manager likes you or not regardless of how qualified you are - so if you want to grow or move into other departments - keep your opinions to yourself and suck up to your manager - sucking up or brown nosing is not my style because I prefer to be authentic and genuine and is why I was never successful at moving into other departments and I was certainly qualified for the positions in which I was applying. POOR LEADERSHIP: Incredibly poor management for such a large corporation, they lack the ability to inspire and motivate staff, management is close-minded & unwilling to listen to staff's input on improvement processes or ideas, which makes no sense (since) employees are the ones that do the work & can determine what processes could work more efficiently (senseless duplication of work - wasteful spending), poor management is probably one of the single biggest reason for the high turnover rates - just look at the number of open positions listed on any job site - this should be the first and most obvious clue that their is a problem - In all fairness - this can vary in every department but is still a common issue in my experience; FAVORITISM: I suppose this can happen in any job but it was blatantly obvious within the department I worked in and made the daily processes very difficult - our manager was bipolar and everyone's day depended on her mood - she was particular close to a handful of employees that were chronically late, lazy, and constantly MIA leaving work stations unattended and when reported to leadership - nothing happened and things did not change - except for the person that reported the issue - use your imagination.

pros: 6 weeks PTO from the beginning. Almost too much. They make it hard for you to take it.
cons:
No Policies and procedures or SOPs in my area so everyone does things their own way making it difficult to do things the same. Ive only been working 6 weeks and have been written up already for not doing things right.
Training is lacking. I had to figure things out on my own because staff didnt know how to train on procedures.
Pay is under market value for similar positions in the area. 
No OT pay in my area but if work over its comp time =PTO. Not encouraged.
Lots of micromanaging.

review_title: Great physician support in the ICUs.
pros: Respiratory & Critical Care Physicians are invaluable to the ICUs @ IU Methodist. These physicians and nurse practitioners make it great for patients and staff by covering their needs both day and night.
cons: Management is determined to cut costs. Sadly, the company sees cutting out staff members over 50 years of age as a viable strategy. The hospital is sacrificing their knowledge base by eliminating these valuable resource members.

pros: well known company,  good Manager, consistent hours, and competitive pay
cons: Removed premium pay and took huge pay cut to stay, didn't need benefits but had no choice if wanted a job there. Sometimes looked over for advancement (need to be very vocal and confident if want to climb the ladder- which may have been my bad), Some eat there young mentality from senior nurses (it gets better and this can be pretty common in nursing from what I hear)

review_title: Great place to work - if you are in the right department
pros: Management lets you know you are valued. You feel as if you really do make a difference in patient's lives. Great benefits, flexibility for family.
cons: No set policy on employee production levels. There are no reprimands or fear of losing your job if you are doing it incorrectly and adversely affecting other areas of business or patient safety.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Indianapolis, IN
pros: A few co-workers and doctors were great.Not much else!
cons: Everything else! Overpriced insurance benefits, lame & inexperienced managers who show favoritism then leave after a year, poor overall work culture,overpriced cafeteria food, upper management who are out of touch, lazy workers who use race card, 401k plan with too big to fail bank,high turnover rate,overpaid CEO,no respect for employees,no allowance for celebrating holidays on units,no tuition reimbursement unless you sign contract that you will remain a slave in their lousy employment after school, culture of fear of losing your job-you name it, they rank dead last! Don't listen to tv commercials stating they are the best.These ads are false advertising and should be pulled and not given airtime.

review_title: Love What I Do But Like The Company
job_title: Customer Service Analyst in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Help patients with their billing, working with some great team members, learning about the different aspects of healthcare.
cons: Not enough time to do the job correctly, angry patients, nothing moves quickly in this company and even though we do the most in our building we are on the low end of the totem pole.  This makes for non-caring agents and this needs to be fixed.

pros: A truly wonderful place to work. I travel out of my way to be able to work there. Coworkers that actually care.
cons: Playoffs cause you don't in patient care. Attempts to save money have outweighed attempts to truly take care of the patient the way they should be.

review_title: Too Much Change, To Short of Time
job_title: Clinical Business Manager in Bloomington, IN
pros: Overall vacation, healthcare and sick time is great.  Since it is health care it is open 24/7 and you the option to find a variety of shifts.
cons: When IU Health took over Bloomington Hospital, they made too many changes to quickly.  One week we were training to do the "Disney Way" of customer service, and the following week we were trained on Lean Six Sigma.

review_title: They have a bad reputation in the employer market for a good reason
job_title: IU Health Plans in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Good benefits; lots of PTO
cons: Management team is made up of low grade, just got out of school and have absolutely no real world experience.  They are inexperienced and extremely immature.  They perpetuate the negative reviews.

review_title: Use to be the best place
pros: Innovative technologies, hard working staff that actually care about their patients,  and not about money which is obvious since they are the lowest payer in the area.
cons: Decrease in staff,  increased patient load makes for unhappy staff, every one is bitter,  atmosphere is horrid stab your Co workers in the back to make sure your job is secure is the current mentality

job_title: RCIS Systems Analyst in Indianapolis, IN
pros: The only Pros is that the employees get a long, want guidance, direction and great leadership however that is what they do not have,
cons: Employees that are not friends of the leadership team stands no chance at job promotion. No matter what your experience is you wont get a chance. Diversity is a real issue with the company there is NONE in Leadership

review_title: Could be a great place to work
pros: Very good salary and benefits.  Great facility.  Wonderful co-workers.  Continuing education opportunities
cons:
Downsizing and centralizing by a top executive who isn't in touch with the realities of working with patients and insurance companies.
Staff often treated like machines.  No talking, limited bathroom and water breaks.

pros:
Those that you work with become your family. There is a bond between coworkers that carries on throughtout the working relationship. Many of us share activities outside the work environment.
Good pay with great benefits.
cons:
There is the constant fear of your job being eliminated du e to downsizing.
Holidays are paid holidays only if you have PTO hours to use, otherwise the holiday is not paid.
Communication is not always at its best.

review_title: Lacking in caring for their employees.
job_title: Patient Care Assistant in Indianapolis, IN
pros: The people you work with on a daily basis are great to work with and can make friends for life.  Also loved working with the public and helping them in their time of need.
cons: With current downsizing and job cuts, it's beginning to be scary the amount of pressure they are placing on the nurses by taking away resources that are needed.  Communication is lacking.  Money is becoming more important than patients.

pros: A lot of opportunities within the large company, fairly flexible when family needs come up last minute (at least the clinical manager and shift coordinators are), so many cuts have led to huge bonuses for working overtime, Magnet status
cons: High turn over and low amount of experienced nurses because of it, tight budget and limited resources (including staff) which leads to very unsafe patient care, expensive insurance, poor training of nurses (orientation just gets shorter and shorter and new employees are being trained by new employees, not the seasoned ones), below market pay for most nurses (new nurses hiring in at a higher pay rate than seasoned nurses), highest raise you can get now is 2% which is performance-based, terrible attendance policy (allowed 3 call ins per year before counseling begins), poor flexibility in scheduling (in advance/when making the schedule), horrible uniforms that you purchase with your own money and they're not even discounted...if you can even get a hold of one because you have to buy online and pay shipping and they're always out of stock (our new hires wear hospital scrubs for months when they are waiting for their shipment to arrive), several travelers throughout the hospital two years after the big rift, senior management doesn't consider the input from bedside nurses, terrible communication between the health care team and between senior management and employees at ground level

review_title: They try? But for me, it was a miss...
pros:
- Benefits are fine 
-401k is average/ slightly above average, and they will have people from the 401k company in to chat about your options which is nice
-Hours for my role were very fair — rarely stayed past 5
-Role was located at Fairbanks, which is right on the Canal and makes for nice scenery 
- I heard they gave out a bonus this year which is nice!
cons:
1. they try really hard to encourage culture among departments and teams, which is good i guess...but it really doesn’t matter what leadership or “committees” do to encourage culture if your immediate team does not really care to participate, or don’t feel comfortable being themselves at work 
2. there is a false sense of collaboration and teamwork within my department/unit. people from different cohorts will start initiatives together but then not communicate about the status of their portion at all, leaving the project owner/other members feeling unimportant and annoying for having to follow up 1x a week. 
3. dress codes, working from home benefits, and other “work  rules” vary HEAVILY between departments, buildings, and even between floors of the same buildings. It is inconsistent and unfair. 90% of our jobs (my departments) could be done remotely from a computer (I mean how often do we send emails to people who are three cubes in front of us?) so why do we have to state our case when we need to work from home for a day? 
-some leadership is really insensitive to other people’s time. You can’t have every meeting you are in run 20 mins over just because you have direct reports.

review_title: IU Health impact on local hospital
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Bloomington, IN
pros: Hospital staff are truly committed to quality care, and floor directors really try to make things better for staff and patients.
cons: Low morale, high turnover, low salary for local cost of living as compared to Indianapolis IU Health salaries, constant change, inadequate staff education, high stress, frequently understaffed, focus on patient satisfaction exceeds that of staff concerns, unresonable absence policy that forces employees to come to health care environment when ill (really?!), old building, local leaders have very limited authority while IU Health central administration directs budget, salary, etc.

pros: Great coworkers. PTO is good. They a very flexible when it comes to work hours.  Only on rare occasions do you have to put in much more than 40 hours over.
cons:
I would not recommend IU Health for IT workers.  If you have an IT background you are not valued as someone with a medical background such as an RN.  They had job cuts in the IT department to save money.  Before they did this they got rid of the CIO and hired another.  Then they had to hire a few more CIO's under him to help him out.  How is that saving money?  
The raises, when you get one are very low.  Last one was not even 2% and I had a great review.  It does not build much morale when you see the CEO get huge bonuses and raises.  The one year we got nothing due to the company not having the money the CEO did well.  It is also discouraging when they tell us they do not have money for raises but they keep building nice new big buildings.    
You know it is a sinking ship when you see a steady stream of coworkers leaving that have been here for a long time.  No bonuses.
Every year they cut the benefits.  They used to give towards your retirement.  Now they will match up to so much if you can afford it.  If you can it is less than it used to be.  They used to give us gifts during the holidays.  They were not much but it made you feel valued.  One year they said they were not gong to give them that year so they could donate to help those who needed help.  I knew that would be the last time we get anything.  The following year they did not mention anything about them.

review_title: It’s OK as a stepping stone position.
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Muncie, IN
pros: Wonderful nurse management and nursing team on 9N Medical-Surgical Unit
cons: Techs are required to “sit” when a patient needs 1:1 attention. Mostly for SI patients in the ER. It requires 1:1 observation with Q15 min documentation. You are not allowed to have computers available. You may not read or do anything that takes your focus away from the patient. You are expected to continuously watch the patient for a minimum of 4 hours, up to 12 hours. It is a mind numbing job duty.

pros: Large community presence with strong academic reputation due to teaching hospital status.  Competetive benefit package.  Riley Hospital's reputation is the strongest in the state and allows Clarian to rely on that reputation.
cons: Executive leadership out of touch with needs of staff and patients.  Personal accountability is very low.  Fiscal leadership is lacking and cost overruns and program spending is uncontrolled.

review_title: Like my job, questionable about corporate management.
pros: I have great coworkers. I love my unit. I feel good about my job security.
cons: Corporate management gives wishy-washy answers for why they are cutting our pay, and won't be forthcoming on when these cuts will stop, if ever. Health insurance costs are pretty steep for not that great of coverage.

review_title: RILEY- ROC is a great place to work!
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Indianapolis, IN
pros: I love the flexibility and being able to pick up shifts when needed. They are supporters for continuing your education and encourage it. I have an amazing and understanding supervisor.  We are like family and have an amazing team.
cons: Being part-time with benefits is great but since I'm part time insurance is higher and PTO accrual is cut in half. The pay for MAs I believe is below market.

job_title: Licensed Clinical Social Worker in Bloomington, IN
pros: Everyday is different, you may be doing Advance Directives to talking with someone about substance use treatment to assessing all psychosocial needs and everything in between. I feel like I'm really making a difference in patient/families lives.  Love my team and environment. PTO is excellent, no discharge planning.
cons: On call stinks and  compensation for that is not good. Must use PTO for holidays and sick days. Compensation is not competitive.

pros: Pleasant and supportive work environment with a chance to earn a reasonable although not excessive income while providing services that support a benefit for society as a whole. Reasonable to excellent managers who generally communicate well.
cons: Heavier requirement to play "politics" than should be necessary resulting in uneven and sometimes arbitrary distribution of company paid educational opportunities, pay raises, promotions and advancement.

review_title: Image is better than the reality
pros: Worked with an amazing & dedicated group of people that went above and beyond to provide excellent service to largely under-served population.
cons: So concerned with meeting market ranges that benefits & salary were lacking. Organization is not an ideal place for upward promotion. They are more concerned with public image of than employee development or upward mobility. Most benefits provided to management level and above.

review_title: Get ready to brown nose if you want to advance.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Good pay and PTO policy.
cons: Very political environment. Your level of advancement is largely determined by who you know and not the quality of your work. Not much work life balance for non-clinical employees. Required to get their health insurance plan which is very expensive.

review_title: Great company that cares and has values
job_title: Food and Nutrition Services in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Great all around company. Super positive workplace. Excellent investment in team.
cons: Cost cutting measures as a result of the pandemic have affected those across the board. Mostly financially related. Obviously not in quality of care.

job_title: Practice Operations Assistant in Indianapolis, IN
pros: I love the people with whom I work.  The doctors, MAs, and front-office staff are truly a team.  We work hard to give the best service to our patients.
cons: Management does not understand what we do but consistently tries to change policies to make things "better."  Work/Life balance is only considered for those in supervisor positions.  Those in entry level roles bear the full weight of the stress of the day-to-day operations.

pros: Great benefits, very cheap but comprehensive insurance. overall positive atmosphere, great focus on the patients.
cons: My supervisor enforced rules that they claimed were in the handbook or rules and they were not. I approached her supervisor with the hopes of clearing the air and also hopeful that the "open door policy" was legitimate, however the environment became worse after that. I encourage people to really think about going to HR if there is a serious workplace issue, or at least document it with them as you work it out in other channels.

pros: Benefits are available and opportunity to have training under nurses and doctors is effective.  Payroll is biweekly and vacations are approved with adequate notice.
cons: IUHealth has high employee turnover.  Training for new employees is limited and employee is expected to learn all areas quickly.  Free employee parking is limited.

pros:
First started working at this hospital was friendly and everyone knew everyone elses name even from other departments.
 Worked together to help patients and community.
cons:
Over the years the Hospital has changed hands no community support, no longer feel job security as good  co workers left on own or walked out.
 Management can tell you to go home because staff not needed. But can call you on day off and expect you to come in.
Because of lack of job security co workers turn on each other to keep own jobs, encouraged by management.
 High school atmosphere- manager favorites-bad work ethics.

review_title: Poor administration at La Porte Hospital
pros: Great staff, really trying to do a good job under the circumstances.
cons: Did a reduction in force, now serverly under staffed especially nurses. Low employee moral. Poor communication from the top down. They have either fired most middle management or they have left for better positions. Benefits have been reduced each year for the last 3-4 years. Pay is lower than other area hospitals.

job_title: Patient Access Specialist in Delphi, IN
pros: They offer a great work environment based on cooperation and caring.
cons: Paid time off requests must be submitted two weeks in advance so you can not use it for sick days.  This means that points are incurred for these days.

pros: There are many opportunities for advancement and learning throughout 20 plus hospital system.  Pay is competitive locally but we also set the market due to the high number of employees.
cons: Medical Insurance per pay period for a family is over $350.  There are certain departments within Clarian (IU Health) that are overworked and underappreciated.

review_title: Loved it when it was still Clarian
pros: Job security, 12 hour shifts, professional atmosphere, cafeteria open on night shift
cons: Dangerous staffing cuts all through Methodist hospital. Dog kennels and boarding have better staff to client (nurse & aide to patient) ratios. So many staffing cuts to RNs, PCAs, and security that patients and staff are in danger.  Changed employee benefits and tuition reimbursement. I have friends that still work there in many depts and they say it just gets worse and worse.

pros: Pay is OK. Great benefits. Enjoy my co-workers. Been employed over 5 years. Great doctors. Great training opportunities and education reimbursement.
cons: Lots of customer service training for all employees. Either you have good customer service skills or you don't. Sometimes the left hand has no clue to what the right hand is doing. Supervisor has little time to be involved with employees. Supervisor has no clue what goes on in workplace.

pros: Most facilities have good people to work with
cons: IU Health policies are unlike other facilities. Overall benefits are not the best, pay increases are little to none - your job performance does not influence pay, HR controls it.

pros: I really liked my time at IU Health, which was a time of great transition as the organization went under one name. A feeling of pride was evident.
cons: Unfortunately, the organization grew too fast and lots of operational issues persist. A disconnect between upper mgmt and day-to-day staff exists.

pros: Great coworkers. The nurses and most of the support staff were great.
cons: Everything but my coworkers. Very bad management, except for my initial immediate supervisor, he was awesome. When he left, his replacement was a complete Nazi and had no clue what he was doing. I worked in the eduction department and most of the mangers were just god awful. The team doing 99.7% of the work never got  promotions or raises. The printing department sucked. That is about it.

job_title: Guest Service Associate in Indianapolis, IN
pros: It was like a small family ,so warm and carrying. Are staff  went over and beyond to make you feel comfortable from the time you enter until the time you left.
cons: I have no complaints it was such a wonderful job.the experience was great such a wonderful opportunity. The satisfaction survey was excellent

review_title: Its a company with many branches thats stood the test of time.
pros: The patients that you meet are great. Good pay and insurance. Its been around for awhile
cons: They want you to not truly care about other employees. Be a robot or yes man. not here to make an actual difference.

review_title: Very large company, seemingly endless opportunity.
job_title: Certified Nurse Assistant in Laporte, PA
pros: There are lots of Clarian faciltiies out there so not all of 1 facility is the same.  Opportunities for growth within networks and regions are high.
cons:
Working with schedules that are sometimes not fairly distributed
Working in an environment where team players may spell with an I.
This is all individually based and cannot even be generalized to the company as a whole.

job_title: Patient Care Associate in Bedford, IN
pros: They care much more about staffing at my facility than any other place I've worked. My boss cares about us and we have a good, healthy work environment. I also believe in the IU Health system.  They do a lot to get involvement and feedback from their employees.
cons: My floor's shift time starts earlier than I would like, but I missed the opportunity to vote on this issue because it was decided before I began.

pros:
Flexible schedule
Paid PTO
Health insurance available for FT & PT
cons: yo do not get paid enough for the amount of work you are required to do. you sometimes have to do a lot of the patient care yourself or what some nurses feel like they are to good to do themselves. you are very lucky to work with nurses who are fair when asking for help.

pros: Full benefits. Having working in many of the clinics I can say they generally employ very nice people.
cons: There were no promotions in my department and you have to work for a year before you can transfer departments.

review_title: Great benefits, Highly political office environment
pros: Great benefits including premium reduction for completing healthy activities, good work life balance.
cons: Very political environment with the majority of advances going to friends of higher ups and the chosen few.  Office culture is big on brown nosing and smoozing to excel in your career and not based on skill set and experience. Those who have spoken out are usually gone within the year.

review_title: Great place to learn and grow
pros: I enjoy my teammates and the opportunity to work cross-functionally with some incredibly talented people. Leaders within my department care about my professional growth and the growth of their teams. Good work/life balance. I'm not on the front lines of care, but I find it gratifying to know that I'm helping our providers, nurses, and other medical professionals deliver the best possible care to our patients.
cons: The benefits are pretty good, but I expected better/more affordable healthcare coverage.

pros: Co-workers were all pretty close knit.  Patient care was of the utmost importance.  Great benefits package.
cons: Supervisors would assign busy work projects.  Patient numbers went down and although we were limping along (nearly breaking even as a non-for-profit is design to do) IU and IU Health decided to close the doors.  Employees knew this could happen but it happen at a time when it wasn't expected.  I thought we would have another 5 years or so.

pros: Great health insurance and very reasonable premiums.  I do not have to be on call or work nights/weekends.
cons: Pay is not competitive.  Management is less than ideal.  Nurses are often managers for SW with no grasp of the work we do.  Many micro-managers as well.  Very little opportunity for advancement/.

pros: Close to my residence.  Has a good reputation.  Is one of the larger facilities near my home.  Have worked there for many years and I am familiar with it and its staff members.
cons: Only larger hospital near my residence that is an IU Health facility without commuting..

review_title: Great place to work and grow!
pros: Opportunity for growth , leadership development , lean six sigma , wages, and strong integration across system.  Patient care is at the center of the mission , strong brand
cons: FTE approval process - micromanage from corporate - Too many projects at once need to align projects with resources , nurse to patient ratio on some units

pros: Good Nurse Practitioner colleagues to network with, interesting patient mix, fairly good cafeteria, many different specialty NPs to learn from, everyone feeling like they are in the same boat.
cons: Nurse Practitioners are not treated like professionals.  They are expendable.  This is a medical dominant system, in which the many NPs are largely invisible.  Salary and benefits are not commensurate with expertise and responsibility.  NPs have no authority to do the right thing.  This is an extremely patriarchial and hierarchical system.  Non MD staffing, both professional and non professional, are frequently laid to increase profit margins.

pros: Great benefits and environment to work in. Plenty of room for advancement. Good competitive salary. Great training tools.
cons: None so far.... I have been an employee for five years.

review_title: I learned valuable clinical skills and how to appropriately handle challenging situations with patients and families.
pros: This facility had strong teamwork among the staff and the managers involved staff in meetings and committees. The nursing schedule was consistent and there were no mandation policies.
cons: At this facility supplies needed to be more organized. The equipment often would break down and needed to be fixed. The portable work phones often had low battery life or would drop calls in the middle of conversations.

review_title: Would never work here again.  NEVER.
pros: This place will give you a paycheck, and not much more, except a headache, maybe.
cons: Understaffing, rapid changes, lack of consideration for employees, old and dirty facility, redundant systems for documentation, lack of implementation of best practices, poor education, bad morale, poor pay, bad benefits (will not cover spouse if they can get their own insurance).

review_title: Working at this facility made me anxious and feel non important.
pros: It was close to home.
cons: Hospital only cares for the almighty dollar. If they can make you do more work to save a buck....they will. Staffing is terrible. They want 1 person to do the jobs of 5 people.

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Indianapolis, IN
pros: I met some great people there, and learned a lot about myself.
cons: Everything - the work can be tedious. Management is so focused on cost cutting, they sometimes sacrifice quality. There are emphasis on customer service, but employees aren't incentivized to do well. Training is never refreshed if you are clinical. Being in registration, I was treated like a second class employee by most departments I interacted with.

pros: Some staff work together despite under the upper management pressure and mis-direction; others not so well.
cons: This hospital is concerned mainly about outward image rather than fairness to employees or the well-being of patients.  Inwardly, there is confusion.  If you have a problem, don't expect the managers to fix it as they are micromanaged and relatively helpless.

review_title: Worked with a great group and enjoyed the collaborative atmosphere.
pros: A lot of bright conscientious people who understand healthcare.
cons:
Administration at IU School of Medicine was difficult to work with and come to agreement on issues.
The School of Medicines opinion was the only one that counted!

pros: 3 P's--Patients, Providers, and Peers.   They're wonderful people!!!!  This organization puts time, effort, and dollars into understanding these assets and how to help them reach their full potential.
cons: System merging with smaller entities causes an intense desire to preserve local culture. This piece is stressful.  Leadership turnover can lead to unnecessary stress on teams.

review_title: Wonderful place to work, with a variety of opportunities
pros:
1. Company truly wants to help the patients, by providing preeminent care.
2. The work is fast-paced, and interesting.
cons: Current health care model, especially the payment for services hampers the ability to be paid fairly for good care.  Therefore, cuts must to staffing must be made.

review_title: Great organization to work for until accountable care.
pros: It has always been team oriented. Love helping the care giver and giving them the resources they need to excel in their job
cons: Recent budget cuts as well as professional development. Up until last October, I was completely satisfied to retire in this position. A lot has changed since then.

job_title: Med Surg/Ortho Neuro RN in Lafayette, IN
pros: Good experience working with a wide variety of patients. The unit I work on has a mixture of experience and inexperienced nurses. I've always felt comfortable asking for help
cons: Were constantly intensionally understaffed to the point that we aren't giving patients the care the deserve. Often times unable to work the days I request.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in South Bend, IN
pros: They keep up with all the latest innovations. Employees are friendly. Nice area to live in. Going through a lot of change.
cons: Recently acquired by a for profit organization. The majority of upper management has been let go. Unsure of what the future holds for this organization.

pros:
Getting to know the staff in different departments of the hospital
Benefits are good
cons:
Management is terrible. There is no communication at all.
Projects that do not make sense are implemented and then taken out months later
No room for growth unless you suck up to higher management
Most of the IS staff are lazy and unhelpful all throughout each department
Teamwork is nonexistent

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Great health insurance, flexible PTO, and 401k. Discounts on Costco memberships, hotels, and car rentals. Incentives to participate in healthy activities to reduce cost of health insurance. Incredible adaptability for employees to work from home when necessary during the pandemic.
cons: Takes forever to hear back from job applications. Too many things require permission from HR or higher management to get approved. For example: getting permission to hire additional staff when your department is growing.

review_title: Decent to start at, then get out ASAP
job_title: Medical Laboratory Scientist in Bloomington, IN
pros: Decent benefits and starting pay.
cons: As Bloomington Hospital is becoming more like the rest of IU Health some of its good benifits have been taken away and many of its extra perks, eg. daycare, cheap procedures for employess and such have disappeared to be more in line with what the system offers.
